thread.title: 47 Words That Break the Main Gender Rule of...
thread.title_full: 47 Words That Break the Main Gender Rule of...

title: 47 Words That Break the Main Gender Rule of...
text:
Spanish words that end with -o are masculine, and words that end with -a are feminine, right? 
Well, almost always. But there are exceptions — and knowing those exceptions can keep you from sounding silly. 
Those exceptions fall into these categories: Words that are shortened versions of other words. For example, la foto is feminine because it's short for la fotografía . Words that end in -ista as the equivalent of the English "-ist." For example, dentista can be either masculine or feminine depending on whether the dentist referred to is a man or woman. A few words with other endings are treated the same way. For example, modelo can be either masculine or feminine when referring to a human model, but masculine in other uses (such as when referring to a model airplane). Words whose meanings vary depending on the gender . For example, in some areas, la radio means "radio," while el radio means "radius" or "radium." Sometimes la radio is used to refer to the communications medium and el radio for a radio set. 
continue reading below our video 10 Facts About the Titanic That You Don't Know Some masculine words that come from Greek end in -a (often -ma ). Most of these words have English cognates . Words that are just exceptions. 
Here is a list of the most common exceptions to the "masculine o , feminine a " rule: 
el aroma — aroma
